element_texts.text: Completed

Hoopa. Humbaldt Co.
Calif.
Nov. 12. 1906,
My dear Uncle Ed
I will send you this week
by Wells Fargo Ex 48 red
drawings including Wylackie,
Ukie, Little Lake, Concow,
Pitt River, Lower Klamath,
Hoopa, Orleans, Red Wood and
Saiaz Indians.
I made more of the Hoopa
and Lower Klamath here, only
made a few of the Orleans Red
Wood and Saiaz.
The Red Wood Indians are a
distinct tribe by themselves here,
have their own language and
live by themselves. The Saiaz
Completed

Indians live near and on the
Coast their name translated
means Ocean Indians I just had
one Indian Saiaz girl sit for me
here she is in the Government
School here, from here I will
go to Arcata Calif some 60 miles
from here and will try and get
more of the Saiaz Inidans.
I have had fine success here
The head man of the Hoopa
tribe sat for me he is a very
noted Indian, his name is in
History he is called by the Whites
Captain John but his Indian
name is Day-nas-te-ah.
He is a noble character always
been for peace, he is some 95 years
old now and still keeps up
most of the Indian habits.
I have to cross the river in a
Canoe to get to his place.
1168
Completed

(3)
He is a very large well proportioned
man and well preserved.
I got some Deer meat of him
to day (the Deer was shot
yesterday) and I had an Indian
woman broil it over some hot
coals for me and I enjoyed
it. He gave me some dried
and smoked Vension to eat which
was fine.
I go to his place every day
now as I find the very best
types of the Hoopa's there. Tomorrow
I will be through and Wednesday
the 14th I start for Arcata. Cal.
It is rather expensive getting in
and out of here as the roads
are so bad and steep, all
mountain roads.
I met an Indian girl here
11-12-06
Completed

Who was educated in The Carlisle
school in Pennsylvania and also
went to a school in Philadelphia
She is a very bright intelligent girl
and a fine conversationalist I learned
a great deal of the Hoopa Indian
life from her, She would translate
for me what the Indians said,
describe the markings in the baskets
etc. She was a great lover of
Nature so well posted on herbs
roots and flowers and trees it was
a pleasure to talk with her, so
kind hearted and sympathetic.
Her parents are well to do, have a
fine home up in the mountains
She is very musical, and she is
as refined in her manners and
tastes as any white girl.
She goes around and visits the
old Indian people laughing and
jocking with them.
1168
Completed

(5)
There are hardly 200 Indians living
in this Valley, it is a beautiful
place so much wild fruit grows
here that the Indians use and
plenty of water. The Indian girl
told me that in this Valley there
were five gold mines.
These Indians are well to do
are happy and contented and
very industrous and nice people
to be with, no one single
Indian refused to sit for me
and all of them sat so good & so
patient.
You can address me to
Orland Glenn Co 
California as I will be going
there from Arcata. It will not
be long now before I will be
in Oregon.
11-12-06
Completed

Arcata Humbaldt Co.
Calif.
Nov. 16. 1906.
My dear Uncle Ed
I arrived here yesterday
afternoon and got to work
this morning.
I was told at Hoopa that
these Indians here were the
Saiaz Indians but they are not,
they are the Mad River Indians.
There are 18 of them living
in three houses at the mouth
of the Mad River right
where the Mad River empties
into the Ocean. They have
lived there for years and make
their living by fishing and
digging clams.
They told me today that the
Completed

Saiaz Indians live North of here
in Oregon.
At Hoopa there was a Saiaz
Indian girl who sat for me and
a fine type of an Indian girl.
The Mad River Indians are hard
workers they fish sometimes all
night, they make their own
nets. They were very willing t0
sit for me, they are a good
type. Their langague is the
queerest I have yet heard. parts
of it sounds like chickens
cackling. They speak good
English, there is but one little
Indian girl among them.
They keep their houses rather
neat.
They live five miles from here
so I drive out to them in a
livery rig.
1169
Completed

(3) 
They make a good basket something
similar to the Hoopa but of a
different design.
They were glad to have me
among them and talked a good
deal, they do well fishing and
are fine fisherman, they live in
crudely built wooden houses
with a fire place to heat the
house and to cook by.
I always try to get the Indians
to tell me their names and at
times I have a hard time to get
them to tell me, they make
different excuses sometimes
they say they have not got
an Indian name, they all
mainly have a white name in
addition to their Indian name
but I don't want their white
name.
11-16-06
Completed

Sometimes I have to be very careful
in regard to their name, some of
them are superstitious about
telling a white man their name
but as a rule they will tell me
where they will not anyone else.
Dr Hudson told me he was very
much surprised that the Ukiah
and Pomo Indians told me
their names. some of them declare
up and down that they have no
Indian name, in that case I will
show the portrait to some other
Indian and sometimes he will tell
me the name, at Chico I had
a hard time there to get the
Indians name as a rule very
few would tell me but one very
old Indian woman would
whisper the name to me and
make me promise not to tell.
1169
Completed

(5)
One Indian woman at Chico
would not tell me her name but
she said the Indian who was in
the room could tell me.
At Hoopa very few would tell
me and here today I had a
hard time to get the Indians
name, but another Indian told
the Indian to tell me his name
he told him, it was all right
that there would be no trouble
about it so finally he told
but he did not like to. Some
of them get mad at me for
asking them for their name and
sometimes I have been afraid
if I insisted on their name
it might have some effect on
getting some of the others to sit
for me, but that has not
happened yet. After this, I will
11-16-06
Completed

if possible get their names.
This place is 12 miles North
of Eureka the Santa Fe R.R.
runs here.
There is a Pitt River Indian
girl living with these Indians
here she is a fine type I
will have her sit for me.
I will write you again
from here soon.
You can address me to
Orland Glenn Co
California
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1169
Completed

[[HOTEL VANCE
EUREKA, CAL. -- letterhead]]
Nov 19 1906
My dear Uncle Ed
I left Arcata this
afternoon and arrived here
this afternoon.
The boat was scheduled
to leave for San Francisco
tomorrow but they have
had some trouble with
the help on the boat and the
boat will leave day after tomorrow.
I had good success with
the Mad River Indians there
are only a few of them. I got
portraits of the best types
there, among them a noted
Mad River Indian called
Mad River Bill he is a
very intelligent Indian and
looks like a Priest he is
Completed

about as dignified as a
Priest, he told me he was
born there so was his
Grand Father and great
Grand Father, he said he
remembered when no white
people were there.
I took Dinner with the
Indians every day I was
there and had fresh
Salmon caught that
night to eat and cooked
by an Indian woman.
They were as nice as could
be to me, very kind and
agreeable, they are hard
workers, work mostly all
night catching fish.
Of all the Indian langagues
I have heard, their langague
is the queerest, when one
is talking, there is one who is
listening who repeats nearly
half of every thing the other
one is talking about and
in a great many cases
1170
Completed

[[HOTEL VANCE
EUREKA, CAL.

        __________190  -- letterhead]]

(3)
when the listener knows
what the last few words
in the sentence is to be, they
say those words before
the speaker does. I asked
why they did that, they
said they always did so,
it was a custom among
them.
I intended to make a
portrait of the only Mad
River Indian girl there, but she
was so bashful she would
not sit for me, she was
like a little Deer when she
would see me she would
run and hide. Her
Father and the rest of the
Indians wanted her to
sit for me but she
11-19-06
Completed

would not.
The Indians from Ell
River to Mad River a
distance of some 60 miles
all belong to the same
tribe the Mad River Indians,
and speak the same language.
There was one Pitt River
Indian girl with these Mad
River Indians. She is a
fine type and sat for me.
When I get to San Francisco
I will go direct to Orland
the Grindstone Indians are
a few miles from there
they are a fine tribe and
very few of them left so I
am told.
You can address me to
Orland. Glenn Co.
California.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1170
Completed

[[OFFICE OF
HOTEL ORLAND
Best Equipped Hotel in Northern California
E. B. KESSELRING, Proprietor
Fine Wines, Liquors and Cigars      Courteous Treatment To All -- letterhead]]
Orland, Cal., Nov 24, 1906
My dear Uncle Ed
I just arrived here
this evening.
Tomorrow I hire a rig
and go some 28 miles to
the Grindstone Indians.
I will have to stop with
some farmer there or
else with the Indians. I was
four days in getting here.
I could not leave Eureka
Tuesday or had planned
on account of the strike on
the boat, so I sailed on
another boat on another
line Wednesday, we went
some five miles to the
Completed

entrance to the harbor but
could go no further on
account of the high waves
crossing the bar, so we
laid over there 19 hours.
Crossing the bar when the
waves are very high is
very dangerous, several
ships have been wrecked
there and lives lost, but
the next morning the waves
I thought were pretty high
but we crossed all night,
all the passengers were
ordered in and
every thing tied securely.
Tuesday I hired a rig and
drove a few miles out
to where the Mad River
Indians live near Eureka
but only two Indian women
were at home, one was a
1171
Completed

[[OFFICE OF
HOTEL ORLAND
Best Equipped Hotel in Northern California
E. B. KESSELRING, Proprietor
Fine Wines, Liquors and Cigars      Courteous Treatment To All

                  Orland, Cal.,_____________190  -- letterhead]]

(3)
half breed and I did not
like the looks of the other
woman, she would not sit
for me any way, the rest
of the Indians mostly were
at Mad River near Arcata
fishing. I got good
types of these Indians
near Arcata.
There is no mail going
out to the Grindstone
Indians but I will mail
you a letter here after my
return from there. I will
be in Oregon in a few weeks
now.
You can address me to
11-24-06
Completed

Redding. Shasta Co. Calif.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1171
Completed

Elk Creek. Glenn Co.
Calif.
Nov. 25. 1906.
My dear Uncle Ed
I just arrived here,
left Orland this morning by
livery team and drove 31 miles
to here.
I could not stay at the
Farmers I intended to, his
wife was not well, otherwise
he said he would be glad to
accommodate me, so I came here
which is four miles from
where the Grindstone Indians
live. We passed by their village
so I stopped and went to
their village, I should judge
their was some 25 Indians
living there and they look like
Completed

good types, they are a distinct
tribe and have their own langague.
Years ago the Indians away
from here need to fight them.
Round Valley where I was for
the Ukies, Wylackies and five
other tribes in some 68 miles
across the mountains from here.
This place is a small town
one Hotel, Store, Post Office
two Livery Stables Meat Market and a Saloon here,
the mail comes here every day
except Sunday.
The Grindstone Indians live on
a bluff where the Grindstone
River empties into the
Stoney Creek. They live in pretty good
wooden houses.
I did not tell them what I
wanted of them today but
1172
Completed

(3)
to inquire the way here.
I will go to them tomorrow and
am sure I will have good
success with them.
I expect to be here a few
days.
Will write you again soon.
You can address me to
Redding Shasta Co. Calif.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
11-25-06
Completed

Elk Creek. Glen Co.
Calif.
Nov 26. 1906.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I was out to where the
Indians live at Grindstone Creek
and I have been misinformed
in regard to these Indians. I have
been told by several white people
that they were the Grindstone
Indians.
I met an Indian there today
who is a very intelligent Indian
and speaks English fluently
He told me there was no such
Indian as a Grindstone Indians
he says we are called that
by white people because we
live by the Grindstone Creek.
He told me that the Wylackie
Completed

and Concow (he is a Concow) lived here
and that there were only two
old Indian people living of a tribe
called the "Sun pum" Indians
that these two people lived here
they are all that is left. their
home originally was some two
miles from here where they have
always lived and were born
he said they derived the name
Sun pum from a mountain
there which the Indians called
Sun pum which means "Rock
Mountain" the old Indian of
the Sun Pum sat for me and
the Sun Pum Indian woman has promised
to sit for me tomorrow. Then
there are only three of another
tribe living there one man
and two women they are
called the Kolieh Indians
Completed

(3)
and I will get them to sit for
me. There are hardly 25 Indians
living there, they are absolutely
independent of the Government
They are living on land that
belongs to a Mr Julien he told
them they could have it for their
home, it is a nice place, they
do a little farming and also
work for the white people
some of them heard sheep for
the white people.
They make a fine basket there
finely woven better than most
of the Indians.
They still keep up their dances
they have a large Indian
dance hall.
I met a man at Hoopa
who is a Blacksmith for the
Government Indian School there
11-26-06
Completed

He used to be located at Fort Sill
where Geronimo is he said that
Geronimo to his own knowledge
had $10,000 in the Bank that
Geronimo had made or saved
since he has been at Fort Sill,
he says the Apache Indians
there are given Government
contracts to fill. The Government
years ago gave the Apache Cattle
and the increase in these Cattle
has made them well off
because they are workers and
they are smart bright people
and take good care of what
they have. I noticed this
especially when I was there
and it is especially true of
Geronimo. I will write you again
soon. Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
Completed

acknowledged 12/12
Elk Creek. Glenn Co.
California.
Dec. 4. 1906.
My dear Uncle Ed Recv 12/12
I will send you tomorrow
by Wells Fargo Express 31 red
drawings including Mad River,
Nomelackie, Kabahlmen, Sun Pum
and other Me ten eck Indians.
I am having good luck here
There are only 25 Indians here
and five distinct tribes among
them, only one Concow Indian
lives among them. I did not
have him sit for me and I
got all the Concows I wanted
at Covelo. There were only two
Nomelackies among them, they
are almost extinct, scarcely
six of them living.
Completed

There are six Kabahlmen Indians
among them, there are very few
of this tribe left. Their original home
is some 10 miles from here.
There are only two Sun Pum
Indians living an old man and
old woman, both sat for me
and there are but two
Me ten eck Indians living
both old people a Brother and
Sister both sat for me.
These two Me-ten-eck Indians
live two and a half miles from
where the Indians live on
Grindstone Creek, they own so they tell me 60
acres of land there. Their original
home is but a few miles from
here. The Indians invited me to
see a dance on Thanksgiving
which was very interesting and
different from any Indian
Completed

(3)
dance I have seen, they still have
their old Indian costumes for
their dances made mostly of
feathers, They have got a man
who is called the feather man
whose duty it is to take care of the
feathers belonging to their costumes.
I never was with nicer Indians
than these here.
Among these 25 Indians there
are six different Indian
langague so they speak
principally English.
They are very industious, hard
working people, They all make
fine baskets.
I am going to Redding Calif
from here which is North of
here. there are lots of Indians
12-4-06
Completed

there but what tribes they belong to I
do not know now, but will
find out, the Indians here
do no know, They tell me
that they are a different tribe
from them.
The Me ten eck Indian named
Wy-cou'-e-wie-tah? is an
Indian Doctor here.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1174
Completed

Redding. Shasta Co.
Calif
Dec. 8. 1906.
My dear Uncle Ed
I arrived here this
morning and got to work
at noon with the Indians here.
There are two tribes of Indians
who live about a mile from
Redding There are but a few
of Them left, one tribe is called
The Yanah and The other tribe
I have not learned. 
There are Three other different 
tribes who are stopping here 
temporarily one is The Big Bend 
the other the Big Medow and
the other I have not yet 
learned, They came here last
Fall to pick hops and They
Completed

have put up some crude shacks
and some have tents and the they
are fishing for Salmon now, an old
Indian woman belonging to
The Big Medow tribe sat for me
Today, these Indians are a fine
type have their own distinct
langague and are different
looking from any I have visited
Their home is some 100 miles
North East of here in the mountains
this town is their nearest railroad,
there are enough of them here so I
can get good types of them.
They make a basket similar to
the Hoopa Indian but different
design. They tell me that there
are but few full bloods
living of the Big Medow Indians,
all that are here are full bloods.
1175
Completed

(3)
Their cheek bones are very
prominent and their features are
not as refined as the Hoopa
and are a lighter color than
some Indians.
Their langague sounds funny,
they talk very fast.
I had quite a time to get
the old Indian woman to sit
for me but finally she
consented, so it will be easy
for me to get the rest to sit
for me, or which ones I
will want.
The Yanah Indians live
just across The Sacramento
River from here and are a
good type but a fierce
looking Indian from what
I saw.
12-8-06
Completed

I will write you again in
a few days.
You can address me
here.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
P. S. The old Indian woman would
not tell me her name, They seem
supersticious about telling a white
man their name. I have to be careful
about getting their names when they
do not like to tell me, but I will
get her name if possible before
am through with them.
1175
Completed

[[Shasta County is the banner unclear county of California.
The production of mineral wealth in 1902 was
$8,000,000. The annual production of gold and silver is
$1,000,000; copper $7,000,000.
Hotel Lorenz
GILLESPIE & HOYLE
Proprietors -- letterhead]]
Redding, Cal., Dec 13 1906
My dear Uncle Ed
I will send you
tomorrow 19 red drawings
by W. F. Ex Co. including
Big Bend, Big Medow,
Nahsah and Wintoon
Indians, There are very
few of these tribes living.
I had quite a time to get
them as most of them
work for the whites
and at odd jobs.
I had to cross a Canal
and also cross The
Sacramento River by boat to
get the Nas sah Indians
Completed

only one family were there
an old man and his
wife and a little
niece of theirs, all three
sat for me, the old
man spoke good
English as well as his
wife and he told me
a good deal about
these Indians, he says
They are nearly all dead,
all these different tribes
were born in the Sourrounding
mountains.
An old Indian woman
sat for me Today a
Wintoon Indian she is
a fine type, her face
tatooed, a few of her
tribe live 40 miles
from here at a place
called Delta on S.P.R.R.
Completed

[[Shasta County is the banner unclear county of California.
The production of mineral wealth in 1902 was
$8,000,000. The annual production of gold and silver is
$1,000,000; copper $7,000,000.
Hotel Lorenz
GILLESPIE & HOYLE
Proprietors
Redding, Cal.,___________190_ -- letterhead]]
(3)
I will go there tomorrow
and get some more of
her tribe.
All these different tribes
make baskets, similar to the
Hoopa basket.
Several years ago a great
number of these Indians
were moved over to the
Round Valley where
Covelo is, where I was
but after a while they
left, most of them and
returned back to their
original birth place.
The Modoc Indians
live some 160 miles from
12-13-06
Completed

here by stage but now the
roads are so bad and so much
snow that I will not go to
them until Summer. I may
find Modoc's in Oregon if I
do. I will not return here but
if I do not I will return here
next Summer and go to them.
Enclose I send you two photos,
one of the house is a fair sample
of some of the houses the Indians
live in and the kind of houses I
work in, the woman knealing
is a Ukie Indian she sat for
me, she is preparing breakfast.
The other photo" is of me standing,
in front of a Hoopa Indian
house, this is the old original
Hoopa house that they used
to live in, a large hole is dug
in the ground and the house
built around the hole all
the board are hewn out by
the Hoopa Indians.
Completed

[[Shasta County is the banner unclear county of California.
The production of mineral wealth in 1902 was
$8,000,000. The annual production of gold and silver is
$1,000,000; copper $7,000,000.
Hotel Lorenz
GILLESPIE & HOYLE
Proprietors
Redding, Cal.,___________190_ -- letterhead]]
(5)
I believe this is the only
original Hoopa house in
existence and old Indian
Hoopa woman lives in
this house she is sitting
down at my right.
I got good types here
You can address me to
Yreka. Siskigon Co.
California.
You affectionate
nephew.
Elbridge.
12-13-06
Completed

[[THE DELTA HOTEL
F. L. DIMOCK, Proprietor
BAR AND FEED STABLE IN CONNECTION -- letterhead]]
Delta
Bayles P. O., Cal., Dec 15 1906 answd 12/20
My dear Uncle Ed
I arrived here last
night and got to work
this morning.
This place is in the
mountains, there are only
three or four families of
Wintoon Indians here
one family There is but
one old Indian man,
he sat for me Today, he
lives all alone in a
hut on the side of the
mountain and when I
called this morning he
was still in bed. I
hustled him out of bed
in a hurry and soon
Completed

[[THE DELTA HOTEL
F. L. DIMOCK, Proprietor
BAR AND FEED STABLE IN CONNECTION
Bayles P. O., Cal.,______________190_ -- letterhead]]
(2)
he was sitting for me.
He looks as though he
was 100 years old and
he is a full blood
Wintoon Indian, he said
he was 30 years old
before he ever saw a
white man, The Wintoons
were born right here, but
they have scattered, but
most of them have died
The old Indian gets help
from the County, nearly
all the old Indians
get some money every
month from the County.
There is another family
of but two old people
man and wife and
12-15-06
Completed

[[THE DELTA HOTEL
F. L. DIMOCK, Proprietor
BAR AND FEED STABLE IN CONNECTION
Bayles P. O., Cal.,______________190_ -- letterhead]]
(3)
another family of four
in five with a boy and
girl, so I guess I will
get all the Wintoons
I want here.
These Indians make a
fairly good basket
similar to the Hoopa's.
The land is allotted to
these Indians and They
live on their own land
and have their papers,
entitling them to their
land.
These Wintoon's are
small people, like the
Hopi (Moqui) Indians
their features saw sharper
and more refined than
12-15-06
Completed

[[THE DELTA HOTEL
F. L. DIMOCK, Proprietor
BAR AND FEED STABLE IN CONNECTION
Bayles P. O., Cal.,______________190_ -- letterhead]]
(4)
most of the California
Indians.
I will write you again
before leaving here.
You can address me
to Yreka. Siskiyou Co.
Calif.
Your affectionate
nephew.
Elbridge.
12-15-06
Completed

Yreka. Siskryou Co. 
Calif.
Dec 18 1906. 
Mr dear Uncle Ed 
I arrived here
yesterday afternoon.
I remained at Delta
a short time, two
Indian men and me
Indian woman Sat
for me, the other Indian
family There I did not
like their looks, They
did not look like
full bloods to me so
I did not have them
sit for me, an Indians
Completed

there told me that there
were some Wintoon Indians
living here.
There are very few
Indians living here.
I was out to their place
this morning and one
of them a Wintoon sat
far me, then is but one
family and an old
man who lives by him
self of the Wintoon's here.
In the family there are
four children all fine
types. I had quite a
time to get their consent
to sit for me but
finally I got them.
There are five or six
Shasta Indians living
1178
Completed

(3)
here among them an old
Indian woman with her
face tattooed, They are
a very fine type of an
Indian different from
any I have seen, They have
promised to sit for me.
A Shasta Indian woman
told me this morning
that nearly all the Shasta
Indians were dead, there
are three families living
in the mountains some
24 miles from here, but
I think I can get what
I want here, from what
was told me South of
here I had supposed
12-18-06
Completed

that there were quite a
number of Indians here
but I dont think all told
there are more than 12 or 15
Indians here.
The Shasta Indians
make a basket similar
to the Hoopa only different
design, the old Indian
woman showed me a
basket Today with an
animal's woven in
the design.
I notice all the Indians
who live North of Ukiah
and North of Chico
make a soft or pliable
blanket. The Shasta Indian
women wear a basket
on their heads same as
1178
Completed

(5)
the Hoopa Indian wonder.
The Wintoon and Shasta
Indians here live near
each other, the Wintoon Indians
told me he owned his land
but the Shasta Indian
said he owned his house
but that the land belonged
to a white person.
They cut wood and haul

My dear Uncle Ed.

Field Columbian Museum, the
University of Philadelphia Museum and
the Smithsonian at Washington
in regard to making red drawing
portraits of every American tribe of
Indians at $10.00 for each portrait
I have heard from the Field Columbian
Museum and they are to bring the
matter up at their next meeting.

corresponded with me now and
then ever since I have been among
the Indians in regard to portraits
of the Indians.
The work ought to be done and
soon it will be too late.
I am quite sure that I can
visit every tribe of Indians in
America and make 20 portraits
from each tribe in from 8 to
10 years.

and said she had ordered one of
the Indian women to cook us a
fine Dinner of Salmon, fresh
caught. The old Indian woman
had the Salmon all cut and
ready to broil and when we
came she broiled it over hot
coals and with it we had
Acorn soup cooked by putting
hot stones in the water where
Acorns had been ground up fine
It was a fine Dinner and I
enjoyed it.
These Hoopa Indians are about
the happiest Indians I have been
to they live in such a beautiful place

and have all the Deer they want to eat
and all the fine fish they care
for besides fine Apples grow here
and plenty of wild berries etc.
I leave tomorrow morning by wagon
road 45 miles to Korbel where
the railroad is, it takes two days to
get there on account of the steep
roads. a Hoopa Indian takes me
to town, then I go to Arcata Calif
for the Saiaz Indians then I
will go to San Francisco by boat
and be up North on the other
side of mountain range to
Orland Calif.
You can address me to
Orland Glenn Co.
Calif
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
